title: Guidance on Quality Questions
text:
This guidance provides a set of questions to help analytical and statistical teams evaluate the quality of their analysis throughout the production cycle. We hope that this guidance would help in meeting the Office for National Statistics’s (ONS) strategic objectives for improving statistical quality.1
The aim of producing this guidance is:

To ensure there is a consistent end-to-end QA approach across divisions/departments.

To make it easier to comply with the good practice guidance i.e., The Aqua Book guidance and Code of Practice for Statistics.

To ensure there is a consistent understanding of roles and responsibilities towards producing high quality analysis and statistics.

To make it easier to produce important project documentation i.e., assumptions and decisions log , Quality Improvement Plan (QIP) and risk and issue register etc.

This guidance sits alongside a) Aqua book2 , which provides good practice advice on how to quality assure analysis in government and b) Code of Practice for Statistics, which sets the standards that producers of official statistics should commit to. Two other guidance have motivated us to produce this. One is Analysis Function guidance on Quality questions and red flags and the other is Office for Statistics Regulation (OSR) guidance on Thinking about quality when producing statistics. Both of these guidance provide a set of questions that analysts producing statistics can use to interrogate their work and assure its quality.
Building on these cross-government resources on good practice, this guidance separates quality questions relevant for each stage of analytical cycle. The quality questions will only be fit for purpose if they are asked at the right stage, once that stage is passed, it will be difficult going back and address the risks.
Each question is linked with the Code of Practice for Statistics which is based on three pillars - trustworthiness, quality and value. The idea is to emphasize on the importance and relevance of each question in light of the three pillars. It would also help the analytical/statistical teams better understand and apply these principles through out the project life cycle.
Quality questions are also separated as per the responsible individuals required for answering them. The idea is to highlight a clear line of accountability as per the Aqua book guidance in an easy-to-understand manner. The hope is to make it easier for the teams to clearly see the Aqua roles.

title: Guidance on Quality Questions
text:
Structure of the guidance
There are 60 questions in total covering all stages of analytical cycle. Answering 60 questions may seem a daunting task but this log of answers would later help you in fully understanding the Aqua book and in ensuring your analysis/statistics complies with Code of Practice. It would also help you in writing the analysis/output report along the way. Moreover, most of the answers would help in producing other important documents, for example, assumptions’ log, decision log, technical guide for users, QIP etc.
The Aqua book has divided the stages of analytical cycle into:

Scoping

Design

Conducting and checking analysis

Delivery

Each stage is further sub-divided into the following tabs:

a) Quality Questions
This tab lists the quality questions relevant for each stage of analytical cycle and it provides space in the form of editable text boxes (with no word limit) to write the answers. We encourage commissioner, analyst and analytical assurer to answer all questions as per their responsibilities identified in the introduction.
As user needs or project aims may change over time, the template allows you to edit answers by simply changing the text in the editable text boxes. To track these changes, the person writing the answer should include their full-name, the date they have added the answer, and the date the next review is due on.
Senior responsible owner (SRO) needs to sign-off all the answers. Its best to complete and save log of answers for each stage of analytical cycle. Answers can be saved by pressing Ctrl+S. To undo a action press Ctrl+Z. Pressing Ctrl+S will automatically download a copy of the page on your machine.


b) Importance
It emphasizes on the importance of understanding each quality question and explains the potential risks and benefits around it.


c) Code of Practice for Statistics
It shows the pillars and principles of Code of Practice for Statistics a quality questions relates to. The text in this column is copied from Code of Practice for Statistics. The Code is not concerned only with official statistics. It provides producers of non-official statistics with a framework they can voluntarily comply with.


d) Aqua roles and responsibilities
It explains the responsibilities required to deliver analysis that is fit-for-purpose. It links the quality questions with relevant responsibilities at each stage of analytical cycle as identified in the Aqua book. The roles and responsibilities in this tab are copied as is from AQUA book.
The Aqua book recommends the creation of four identifiable roles to cover different areas of responsibility- SRO, commissioner, analyst and analytical assurer.
Responsibilities of SRO
- A Single Responsible Owner for each model throughout its lifecycle.
- Sign-off all important decisions made about a model to ensure that it is fit-for-purpose, prior to its use.
Responsibilities of Commissioner
- Ensures that context is understood so QA is appropriate and proportionate.
- Ensures that there is enough time and resource for required assurance and account for risk.
- Must understand strengths and limitations including uncertainty so results are interpreted correctly.
- Delivers QUALITY OF OUTCOME.
Responsibilities of Analyst
- Assist the commissioner in framing the question to ensure the right analysis is done.
- Manage external specialists.
- Design, build, document and run the analysis.
- Delivers QUALITY OF CONTENT.
Responsibilities of Analytical Assurer
- Ensures that the evidence is there to demonstrate that appropriate QA has happened and uncertainty is communicated appropriately.
- Advises the commissioner on whether appropriate QA has happened and about any outstanding risks.
- Involved throughout from design through to use.
- Delivers QUALITY OF PROCESS.

For teams, who are in the middle of an analysis, they can still use this guidance to reflect on the quality questions at the scoping and design stage and continue recording the answers up until the delivery stage.

title: Guidance on Quality Questions
section: Which outputs this guidance apply to?
text:
Which outputs this guidance apply to?
The guidance applies to both ad-hoc releases and more regular outputs.
Regular outputs often fulfil at least one of the criteria of “business critical model” (i. drives essential financial and funding decisions; ii. essential to the achievement of business plan actions and priorities; iii. must be error free or else risk serious financial, legal, reputational damages or penalties). They require the highest level of scrutiny and the governance arrangements must be appropriate for the level of risk.
Ad-hoc outputs with quick turnarounds and limited time and resources, the analysis still requires good quality assurance to avoid costly mistakes. Ad-hoc outputs are often used as an evidence to make important policy decisions.
We strongly encourage the responsible owners of both regular and ad-hoc outputs to answer all questions relevant to their role. Completing the log of answers will only require a few hours of their time and it will make the team more confident to raise quality and resourcing issues, push back against unreasonable demands and to understand and communicate the potential risks right at the scoping stage.

section: How to identify SRO, commissioner, analyst and analytical assurer?
text:
How to identify SRO, commissioner, analyst and analytical assurer?
Whilst the Aqua Book refers to commissioners, SRO, analysts and analytical assurers, it is the responsibilities identified that are important, not the name of the role. The Aqua Book makes no statement of the particular level of seniority or grade of each of the occupiers of the roles — this will vary from project to project.
We suggest an SRO and commissioner to be at Grade 7 or above. If you are still unsure of deciding the roles among your team, please email ASAP@ons.gov.uk with “modelling” in the subject header and we will help you in making this decision.

Quality Questions


Why do I need to know the answer to this?




Q1


What question is the analysis trying to answer?


A clear understanding of the question is essential. It enables your team to scope out requirements, understand the strengths and limitations of the analysis and ensure that it is fit for purpose. If the question is unclear you risk designing and delivering analysis which does not meet user needs.




Q2


Why do we need to answer this question?


Exploring and understanding the need for, purpose of and end use of analysis will help you to understand the importance and impact of your work, how it supports decision making and how others will use it. It will also help you to make sure that all stages of analysis are fit for purpose and that the final output correctly answers the question you began with.  




Q3


Which organisational priorities does this work address?


Setting out how the work aligns with organisational priorities helps you to understand how the work fits with wider strategic objectives and how important it is to carry out the analysis now. It informs the level of assurance needed to make sure the work is fit for purpose.




Q4


Is the model business critical?


Identifying if the model is business critical helps to define the level of assurance needed to ensure it is fit for purpose.




Q5


Who needs to know the answer?


If you don’t know what your outputs will be used for, you cannot be sure that they will meet user needs. A good understanding of likely use cases and how you prioritise them is an essential part of making sure that all parts of your analysis are fit for purpose.




Q6


Who do we need to consult to make sure we meet the right user needs?


Analysis must be well understood by relevant users, or else risks scope creep and misspecification. You should identify stakeholders and users who should be consulted before designing an analysis and take account of their views and considerations  wherever relevant. Consulting the right stakeholders makes sure that your team and your users have a shared understanding and vision of what is the best way to approach answering the question, what the output should look like, how well the users understand the process, its quality and limitations, and what can be done to tailor the final ouput to best meet user needs.




Q7


How will you know you have answered this question correctly?


Being clear about the outputs required and the level of error that is acceptable is essential for ensuring that the final output is accurate and reliable and that users and your team have a good understanding of limitations and uncertainty. It is also essential when designing verification and validation activities that will help you to check the robustness of results under a range of plausible assumptions about methods and data.




Q8


What is the estimated time and resource required to answer this question (in months)?


Without a clear understanding of time and resource constraints, you may overcommit. It is important to push back against unrealistic demands if the team is not able to set aside sufficent time to effectively quality assure the analysis. The users and commissioner should fully understand and accept the associated risks to quality when time and resource pressures are unavoidable and will mean that there are unavoidable risks to quality. 




Q9


What are the consequences if the work is not carried out now?


Understanding why the work needs to happen now will help you to prioritise and make sure that limited resources are targeted to the right activities.




Q10


What are the consequences if the work is not carried out correctly?


It is important to understand potential legal, financial or reputational consequences if the work is not carried out correctly so that you can design a proportionate set of assurance activities. The nature and extent of the principal risks that the organisation is willing to take in achieving its objectives should also determined alongside informing decision making.




Q11


Who is the commissioner, SRO and analytical assurer of this analysis?


Clear lines of accountability strengthen assurance processes and make sure that important decisions are signed off by the right people. There should be a clear understanding of who is responsible for managing, producing and quality assuring the analysis in the team. 




Q12


What tools and resources will you use during the production process? Are they the best for the job?


Before starting an analysis, identify all the skills and resources needed to produce the final output in a sustainable and reproducible way and to quality assure it at every step. The platform used to host the analysis and the software to build and run the analysis should be appropriate given uses and risks. For example, producing critical outputs in Excel does not comply with best practice and is unlikely to be robust or verifiable.




Q13


Do you have the right internal and external resources and capability to deliver the analysis?


If the team lacks capability, sufficient resource or time, this increases the risk that the analysis will not be fit for purpose or sufficiently assured. 




Q14


What are the anticipated risks of the analysis? Have you discussed this risk with the customers? 


You must identify potential risks and their impact well in advance to enable effective mitigation and quicker, confident decision-making. It is also important that users understand risks to ensure that their expectations and requirements are met. You should document how you have identified and are monitoring and mitigating risks.




Q15


Have you developed a contingency plan to put in place if the mitigation plan fails?


Risks that would have a high impact on the analysis but a low probability of occurring should still be accounted for, or else risk serious harm to the public. Without well designed contingencies we put the public at risk.




Q16


Does the data and model comply with ethical requirements? 


Analysis must comply with ethics standards to ensure public confidence. Data ethics are an essential part of any good analysis. You should consider the ethical implications of the analysis and how they feed through to use of analysis when you create the workflow and report your findings.




Q17


What questions are outside the scope of the analysis?


Limitations affect the workings of the analysis and the quality of outputs and what can be done with them. By being clear about the limitations of the analysis we ensure that we have mitigated or accepted them. Limitations must be documented so everybody using the analysis has a shared understanding of them.  




Q18


Will internal auditing and peer review be performed?


Internal audit and peer review are critical for monitoring and assuring that the analysis is performed appropriately and its meeting the required aims and objectives. The outcomes of the peer review should be documented and any relevant actions and recommendations should be addressed and taken forward.




Q19


Will external experts be involved in development and scruitny of analysis?


Your team should commission external specialists to peer review or audit the analysis in proportion to the risks around the analysis and its use. They should be.able to draw on expertise and experience across government and beyond to get feedback, exchange experience and best practices to improve the analysis.

What question is the analysis trying to answer?


Commissioner, analyst


The commissioner plays an essential role in communicating the commission and working with the analyst to ensure that an appropriate understanding of the problem is captured. 




Q2


Why do we need to answer this question?


Commissioner, analyst, analytical assurer


The analyst must document the purpose of the analysis and the levels of quality and certainty that are required for this purpose. Commissioner and analytical assurer should make sure the work aligns with the stated purpose.




Q3


Which organisational priorities does this work address?


Commissioner


The commissioner is responsible for ensuring that key aspects of the problem, scope and complexities, including programme constraints, are captured and clearly communicated and there is proportionate governance in place to support the analysis and its role in the wider project or programme

Is the model business critical?


Commissioner


All business critical models in government should be managed within a framework that ensures appropriately specialist staff are responsible for developing and using the models as well as quality assurance. In such situations, it is important that the decision-maker has sufficient assurance from a senior level within the organisation before taking the decision. For business critical analysis and modelling, the commissioner should be satisfied with the seniority of the analytical assurer.

Commissioner should ensure appropriate stakeholders have been identified so that the scope and boundaries of the problem can be appropriately explored. Analyst and analytical assurer should also be involved.

Analyst, commissioner


Analyst should explore the requirements, boundaries, and scope with all of the stakeholders ensuring a wide range of perspectives are sought. Commissioner should be involved.

Commissioner, analyst

Commissioner, analyst

The analyst may also have a role in working with the commissioner to establish the optimal balance of these constraints.

What are the consequences if the work is not carried out now?


Commissioner


The commissioner has a role to ensure that there is sufficient time and resource for the required level of assurance to be delivered and that they understand the associated risks when time and resource pressures are unavoidable




Q10


What are the consequences if the work is not carried out correctly?


Commissioner, analyst


The commissioner must ensure that the analyst understands the context of the question being asked. This is so that the latter understands and can assess the likely risks and determine what the appropriate analytical and quality assurance response should be. 




Q11


Who is the commissioner, SRO and analytical assurer of this analysis?


Commissioner


During the engagement phase of the analytical cycle, the commissioner is responsible for ensuring that there is proportionate governance in place to support the analysis and its role in the wider project or programme.




Q12


What tools and resources will you use during the production process? Are they the best for the job?


Commissioner


The commissioner has a role to ensure that there is sufficient time and resource for the required level of assurance to be delivered and that they understand the associated risks when time and resource pressures are unavoidable.




Q13


Do you have the right internal and external resources and capability to deliver the analysis?


Commissioner


The commissioner has a role to ensure that there is sufficient time and resource for the required level of assurance to be delivered and that they understand the associated risks when time and resource pressures are unavoidable.




Q14


What are the anticipated risks of the analysis? Have you discussed this risk with the customers? 


Analytical assurer, commissioner, analyst


Analystical assurer should challenge and test the understanding of the problem. Commissioner and analyst should be involved. 




Q15


Have you developed a contingency plan to put in place if the mitigation plan fails?


Commissioner, Analytical assurer


The commissioner has a role to ensure that there is sufficient time and resource for the required level of assurance to be delivered and that they understand the associated risks when time and resource pressures are unavoidable. If there is a need for urgent action, such as a precaution against unacceptable but uncertain risks, the commissioner may request further analysis or evidence-gathering be commissioned in parallel to inform subsequent adjustments of the policy response when uncertainty is reduced. The analytical assurer is responsible for advising the commissioner on whether appropriate analytical quality assurance has taken place and advising them of any outstanding risks.




Q16


Does the data and model comply with ethical requirements? 


Analyst, commissioner, analytical assurer


Analyst should ensure that, if required, formal ethical approval is provided. Commissioner and analytical assurer should be involved.




Q17


What questions are outside the scope of the analysis?


Commissioner, analyst


There should be a clear understanding of the requirements and scope between the commissioner and the analyst at the commissioning stage. During the engagement phase of the analytical cycle, the commissioner is responsible for ensuring that key aspects of the problem, scope and complexities, including programme constraints, are captured and clearly communicated. 




Q18


Will internal auditing and peer review be performed?


Analytical assurer, commissioner, analyst


Analytical assurer should ensure the level of quality checking of the analysis is appropriate for the decision being supported: All analysis requires some checks, at some level, by another competent person wherever and whenever practicable. Analyst and commissioner should be involved.




Q19


Will external experts be involved in development and scruitny of analysis?


Analytical assurer, commissioner, analyst


Analytical assurer should dry run the proposed approach to see if it delivers as intended. Then consider if the overall approach adequately addresses the complexities of the customer issue for this purpose. It is good practice to engage subject matter experts in this review. Analyst and commissioner should be involved.

Questions


Why do I need to know the answer to this?




Q26


How the data used in the analysis will be processed prior to and during use?


Operations on the data inputs will have wide-ranging effects on processes and outputs. A clear understanding of how these processes affect the workflow is essential for understanding quality.




Q27


Is the data appropriate given the methods selected?


A comprehensive understanding of data inputs is a prerequisite to meeting user needs.




Q28


What are the strengths and limitations of the data that you use? 


Not all data can be usd to answer particular research questions. The formatting, the time scale, the granularity must all be assessed and found relevant to the research question. A comprehensive understanding of data inputs is a prerequisite to meeting user needs. Without understanding where data is strong and where it is weak, it is impossible to make meaningful improvements to the analysis and/or the inputs to manage the limitations.    




Q29


Is there a robust relationship between your team and data providers? Does your data provider have a good understanding of how and why you are using their data? Do you have a good understanding of how the data provider collects, processes and quality assures the data?


A good relationship with data suppliers helps to make sure that the data they supply meet your requirements. Lack of communication can mean you are not aware of quality risks or changes in collection or processing steps that may affect your results. You should be able to communicate with your suppliers as often as you need to to manage input quality. Data providers should also have a good understanding of how and why you are using their data. This can help them to improve data quality, value, and identify and address any gaps or issues that are relevant for your analysis.




Q30


Is there a formal agreement in place that specifies when, what and how the data will be received? If not, do you think this would be helpful?


A formal agreement with data providers makes sure that everybody understands what will be delivered, when and how. It is useful for setting out clearly the division of responsibilities between data providers and your team for acessing and sharing the data, for example, formats, delivery, timescale, legal framework, accompanying metadata and quality checks. 




Q31


Do you know what quality checks are carried out on the data before you receive them?


Data suppliers should be able to demonstrate that their data has been well assured and meets your needs. If there is no evidence of this it is cause for concern. Simply having a quality report is not enough. You should have sufficient evidence to understand that the data meet your needs and that reported quality matches what you observe in practice.




Q32


How will you work with your data provider when your data requirements change?


You should review your data requirements regularly to ensure they are still relevant and feasible. Any change in requirements should be communicated to data providers well in advance and agreed upon by all stakeholders. If there is a formal agreement, it may need to be revised as requirements change. 




Q33


How do you know if your data provider makes a change to their systems or processes, which could impact the data you receive and/or the statistics you produce?


Often the data suppliers make changes to their methodology or systems. This may not necessarily affect the quality of their data but it may impact on how you are processing this data and what findings can you infer from it. We consider it important to demonstrate that bilateral commuication between data supplier and your team is frequent, effective and ongoing so that you get timely information about any changes made by them. 




Q34


How did you choose the methods for the analysis? How do you know the method you are using is appropriate? 


You should be able to explain why you chose the method by explaining the underlying assumptions of the method, its suitabilty for answering the research question and for the type and distribution of data you are using, and how was this decision signed off.




Q35


Are reasonable alternative methods have been explored and rejected for good reasons?


There is usually more than one way to answer a research question and meet the objectives of an analysis. By explaining why other methods/approaches were considered and rejected in favour of the method selected, your team and users can be confident that the chosen method is appropriate. Unless there is evidence underpinning your choice, users cannot be sure that you have alternate methods have been explored and rejected for good reasons.




Q36


How do you know that your analysis or statistical process is working correctly?


You need to be sure that your analysis produces the outputs that you think it should and that the processes you run work as expected. If you cannot demonstrate that scripts and processes you have set up are functioning correctly, you cannot confirm the quality of the results.




Q37


Can you describe the assumptions of your analysis, when they were made and who made them and signed them off?


A clear undersatnding of assumptions is important for understanding how the model/analysis simplifies the world and to mitigate the uncertainties present in every analysis. If assumptions are inadequately set out or absent, assumed characteristics about the analysis and its inputs will be opaque, greatly increasing risk. Without a comprehensive log of all assumptions made by the model, an audit trail back to sources signed off by assumption owners, a version control log reflecting when assumptions were last updated and evidence reflecting internal and external validation of assumptions, uncertainties may go unacknowledged and could drastically impact the outputs.  




Q38


How the assumptions are validated and assured prior to use?


A clear understanding of how assumptions have been externall and internally validated and signed off gives us confidence that they are reasonable.




Q39


How do you measure and report uncertainty in your analysis?


All analysis contain some degree of uncertainty that may come from a variety of sources. Reporting uncertainties is important to inform users of how precisely we can give our reported values or how much confidence users can have in the analysis. It could also help your team to determine where an analysis can be improved. There are many ways to quantify uncertainty in input data, assumptions, processes and outputs. There is no ‘one size fits all’ approach. For instance, the size and distribution of the uncertainties in analytical inputs can be understood by comparing different data sources, understanding the probability distribution, break-even analysis, using expert judgement or historical data to inform ranges. Uncertainty in model outputs can be assessed with Monte Carlo techniques, convolution, scenario analysis,  previous forecasts, expert judgement, etc.




Q40


Have you considered the implications of any unquantified uncertainties?


A good understanding of the uncertainties in the analysis workflow is critical to ensure the model and its outputs are fit for purpose.




Q41


Can you explain the impact of your work/output on downstream processes? Are there any risks around these dependencies?


Understanding how your analysis would be used by the primary and secondary users would help to ensure that the right quality and assurance levels are in place. It would help you to assess the risks around the use of analysis and if there are other stakeholders or users you need to consult.            




Q42


All or part of the analysis is reliant on a single person?


Single points of failure carry significant business risk. If there is only one person who understands how to carry out all or part of the analysis then the process is extremely vulnerable.




Q43


Is it clear why important decisions were made and who made them?


All analysis involves decisions. A comprehensive record of the decisions made in specifying and conducting the analysis ensures that we have a full audit trail of why decisions were made, who made them and signed them off.




Q44


If changes need to be made to any code or datasets, is it difficult to track who made these changes and why those changes were made? 


Good version control ensures that you have a full understanding of when, why and how changes were made to your analysis process. If it is hard to track changes, this makes it hard to retrace steps if there is a problem and means you do not fully understand the process




Q45


Would another analyst be able to reproduce your model output or continue the work (without talking to you first)?


Your analysis must be well documented and repeatable so that somebody new can understand it, pick it up and produce the same output using the same inputs. Poor documentation means that other people will not understand why the process is configured as it is, how the process works, how to run the process safely and produce the same output- potentially leading to errors.




Q46


Do you use internal peer review to check scripts and code, documentation, implementation of methods, processes and outputs?


The team should independently review and validate the logical integrity of its analysis as well as the structure and functionality of the code against the research question the analysis asks. A record of validation and verification activities undertaken, outstanding activities and remedial actions is important to understand that the correct analysis has been performed for the purpose it is used for and the chosen approach minimises risk.




Q47


Is your code and analysis ever peer reviewed by someone outside your team or organisation?


External peer review is one of the best ways to ensure that the analysis and code are well made and fit for purpose. Without it, teams may reinforce their own biases and will be unable to notice there is anything wrong.




Q48


What is the assessment of the quality of your analytical outputs?


Understanding and reporting on the quality of your analytical outputs is critical to ensure fitness for purpose, as well as trust and reliability. This ensures that analysis can appropriately inform decision-making. Your quality assessments are also key information to be shared with your users as well as being a requirement of the Code of Practice for Statistics.




Q49


How do you assure yourselves that analysis carried out is correct?


It is important to aasure the results fit with your expectations and you are able to explain why there are any discrepancies. It makes it easier to mitigate risk appropriately. There are various ways of assuring if the analysis is carried out correctly. For example, sensitivity analysis can help in understanding which inputs are having the greatest effect on the outputs, and which procesess within the model are the most critical.You can also compare figures from your analysis with any similar earlier analysis or test your data against historical series.




Q50

It is crucial to identify unusual trends in the data and understand why you had them there in the first place. Not all outliers are the same. Some have a strong influence, some not at all. Some are valid and important data values and some are simply errors. Outliers should be thoroughly investigated and reasonable steps should be taken to analyse their impact on your final output.

Q41

Analyst, analytical assurer

All or part of the analysis is reliant on a single person?

Analytical assurer, analyst

Q44

Best practice includes the production of validation log books. Analyst should be involved. 




Q45

Analyst, analytical assurer


Quality analysis needs to be repeatable. Analyst should check that the entire analytical process reflects the principles of RIGOUR (Repeatable, Independent, Grounded in reality, Objective, Uncertainty-managed, Robust)




Q46


Do you use internal peer review to check scripts and code, documentation, implementation of methods, processes and outputs?


Analyst


In addition to conducting the analysis, the analyst should also provide proportionate documentation that outlines the verification and validation activities that their analysis has been subjected to. When the analyst is conducting their analysis, they will be performing their own tests to check their analysis and they will commission other verification and validation activities as required.




Q47


Is your code and analysis ever peer reviewed by someone outside your team or organisation?


Analyst, analytical assurer


The people responsible for delivering the analysis frequently assist the commissioner in structuring the question in order to ensure the appropriate analysis is performed. Some analysis may require external specialists and therefore analysts may also have responsibilities as part of the procurement process. Analysts, including those 3rd parties providing analysis, should also provide proportionate documentation that outlines the verification and validation activities undertaken and the associated conclusion. The analytical assurer is responsible for advising the commissioner on whether appropriate analytical quality assurance has taken place.

Commissioner, analytical assurer


As part of the delivery phase, the commissioner should ensure that there is an assessment of the level of analytical quality assurance of the analysis, making note of where there has been a trade-off between time, resources and quality. The analytical assurer is responsible for advising the commissioner on whether appropriate analytical quality assurance has taken place. 




Q49


How do you assure yourselves that analysis carried out is correct?


Commissioner, analyst, analytical assurer


Analyst testing covers those activities where the analyst builds in checks and processes to ensure that their analysis is correct. During the delivery phase, the commissioner has additional important roles, both in providing feedback to assist in the correct interpretation of the results and to determine whether the analysis has addressed their commission. When analyst are conducting their analysis, the analytical assurer can then comment on whether the analysis is still meeting the needs of the commission to ensure best use of the results

Commissioner, analyst


When interpreting the results of a piece of analysis, the commissioner provides constructive challenge and, with the analyst, explores whether further analysis is required. 




Q51


If you find outliers or unusual trends in the data, what steps are taken to investigate them?


Analyst, analytical assurer


If applicable, analyst should undertake parametric analysis to understand the consequences of missing or uncertain data and assumptions. Analytical assurer should be involved.

Q52


Could you give a clear account of what can and cannot be inferred from your final output?


Often the aim of final output (be in the form of data tables, graphs, regression results or commentary around any of them) is to inform decison-making. The final output may represent predictions, involving lots of underlying assumptions. There is a risk that the primary or secondary users may misinterpret the findings, make wrong comparisons, use it for unsuitable purposes and arrive to wrong conclusions. For example, a non-expert user may wrongly interpret correlation as causation or use incomplete or disconnected data for forecast. It is, therefore, important to clearly inform and remind the users about the correct use of the output and what can and connot be inferred from it.




Q53


Have you assessed the impact of the data and model limitations and set out how they will affect the quality and use of the outputs?


It is important to describe why each limitation related to data and methods exist, why it cannot be overcome using the chosen approach and what impact does it have on the quality and interpretation of the output produced. Results are of very little value if limitations aren’t documented and the rationale for them explained.




Q54


Have you sense checked outputs with user groups and stakeholders?


The credibility of outputs should be checked by experts/relevant stakeholders/users and sense checked to ensure they are useful.




Q55


Is uncertainty related to data quality, assumptions and methodology clearly communicated to users?


Outputs will never be 100% accurate. Users will need to understand how uncertainties related to data, assumptions and methodology feed into and through the analysis workflow and what this means for the use of the outputs. Results must clearly set out how uncertainty affects the findings from the analysis, or else we risk misinterpretations and conclusions being overly reliant on imprecise results.




Q56


Are the implications of unquantified uncertainties communicated to users?


Users should be provided with a sound understanding of important uncertainties which have not been captured in the analysis. Where possible, your team should make reasonable judgements about the likely size and direction of the unquantified uncertainty and provide a qualitative description informing users about why they can’t be quantified and what might be their likely impact.




Q57


Is model documentation including technical guide publicly available?


Transparency about your analysis would enable proper scrutiny and challenge, promotes public trust and encourages re-use of the resources you develop.




Q58


Does the technical guide explains how to use the model to obtain valid outputs?


Technical guide helps in understanding the analysis better and in getting familiar with it in less time. A well-written technical guide is esstential to maintain the analysis over the project cycle. It helps both the primary and secondary users of the analysis in replicating it, finding answers to their questions on methodology and in building their trust in the final output. 




Q59


Have you fully documented the model code?


Technical guide can only serve its purpose if the model code is fully documented within it. Model code should be documented in a coherent manner for any new user of the model to understand and execute it as easily and quickly as possible. Code should follow best practice guidance.




Q60


Are users able to feed back on the suitability of outputs?


The more external critique exists within an analysis the better. Users in particular need to be able to feedback to your team to ensure that the results are meeting their needs. User feedback and customer reviews not only act to inform the team of the changes required but also act as evidence that users have been consulted.
